column4: I'd be interested in the better way just out of curiosity if you care to give it.
I'll test that in a minute.
i'd like to know the better way too. I just know there's another one because that one is pretty ugly...
Ah.  Maybe I'll stumble across it.
what about deleting /etc/rc3.d/S13gdm and changing the default init to 3 in /etc/inittab?
That sounds like it would work.  Would have to try it.
what did you tried?
For some reason /etc/init.d/gdm start disables my console switching.
So I'm actually still very much open to ideas.
Just restarted it outside of the boot sequence this time.
so you can't change the TTY using Ctrl+Alt+F#?
Correct.
do you spawn the ttys in inittab?
Don't know.
and Kr0ntab: Once I'm logged in to the desktop, in gnome-terminal I can sudo /etc/init.d/gdm stop.
something like '1:2345:respawn:/sbin/getty 38400 tty1' in /etc/inittab
and Kr0ntab: I then have full ability to switch between my ttys.
and Kr0ntab: I maintain that ability if I then startx from one of them, but not if I start gdm.
I'll look for that.
you should have them, because if not you couldn't switch even when disabling gdm
Ah.
Yeah, I spawn 1-6.
then it should be somthing related to gdm alone...
1 is :2345 while 2-6 are :23 only.
the same as me...
have you changed somthing in the gdm configuration?
So then what?
I don't think I even know how.
Someone suggested a driver conflict of some sort, but I wasn't able to pinpoint anything.
i don't think it would be a driver conflict
If you have any ideas of what it could be, please throw them out here, and maybe I'll find something useful.  Not sure where to even look myself.
i'm reading the gdm.conf, in order to find if there's something that blocks the ctrl+alt+F1
Oh, I have a login theme installed, but that worked before this problem happened.
Okay.
have you tried dpkg-reconfigure gdm, just in case that would change anything...
No, I haven't.  Will do.
and you can change to TTY doing a startx, a X& gnome-session, but you can't when you load the gdm first. Is that ok?
Can I do the reconfigure with it running, or should I stop it first?
you should stop it, just in case it has to do something...
What do you mean by X& gnome-session?  Haven't done that.
with X& you load the xserver in the background, and with gnome-session, i'm not pretty sure (i used fluxbox), but you load the gnome desktop
No go on X& gnome-session.
what did he say?
hmmm, then, to run gnome-desktop you have to run a different thing than gnome-session..
Sorry, ^^.
gnome-session did exist though.
instead of gnome-session run gnome-wm
Okay.
Same thing.
Still have yet to try dpkg-reconfigure gdm, should I do that now?
try it, but i'm not sure it would help you
Okay.
Now I killed it.
what?
* Reloading GNOME Display Manager configuration...
Now /etc/init.d/gdm failed completely.
gdm start that is.
what did you do?
not, just gdm will work
sudo dpkg-reconfigure gdm.
woah, that killed gdm? that's pretty strange...
try sudo /etc/init.d/gdm stop; sudo /etc/init.d/gdm start
nv.  Needed sudo.
But it's scary-looking now.  My fonts, icons, and resolution are all different.
hmm, and all because the dpkg-reconfigure... even the screen resolution?
and it works to change to the TTYs?
It seemed like it.  I didn't actually check in the res setup, but things were different sizes as if it were.
No.  I had that start on display 2 while this was up, and had to kill it to get back here.
i don't have a clue of what's happening...
Nuts.
Can I undo my reconfigure?
Or any clue about the part it said failed?
i don't know, but i'm afraid that you can't
Shoot.
what did fail?
invoke-rc.d: initscript gdm, action "reload" failed.
but that was performed when you did a dpkg-reconfigure or when tried sudo /etc/init.d/gdm stop; sudo /etc/init.d/gdm start ?
sudo dpkg-reconfigure gdm, in that part's output.
see the /var/log/dpkg.log for some info about why it failed
or use http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org to paste the whole file
Um, the file's empty.
that's good... but not in this case...
Any plan B?
sudo apt-get remove --purge gdm; sudo apt-get install gdm?
i think it's too serious...
Well, do we know what it can hurt?
if it only removes gdm and the installs it again it just will broke your configuration for gdm
if it has to remove something more... it's a lot more complicated and dangerous...
Which includes what, my theme and options like "allow remote login" and stuff?
Would it tell me if it's going to do anything else?  (With a switch?)
usually it ask you when apt-get performs something more than what you told it to do
but can also use the synaptic gui interface to apt-get, so you'll see what's going to happen
